Hello everyone.
 
As some of you know, I've been working on a new Heritrix =
module (or rather
modules) that would allow for iterative crawling, which a=
djusts it's
revisits based on observed changes in downloaded documents.
 
W=
ell, an alpha version of this is now, finally, available. It can be
downloa=
ded from here:
http://crawltools.archive.org:8080/cruisecontrol/buildresult=
s/BRANCH-heritri
x-Kris-ARbranch2
It is being developed in a branch of the =
Heritrix project. So, aside from
it's customization, the distribution close=
ly resembles current HEAD build.
 
The distro comes with a profile called d=
efaultARtesting which has already
set up the modules needed. For those want=
ing to build it from scratch, you
must do the following:
 
Set Frontier to =
AdaptiveRevisitFrontier.
 
Then insert the following processors into the pr=
ocessing chain:
ChangeEvaluator - should be at the very top of the extracto=
r chain.
WaitEvaluator - in the post processing chain.
 
The ARFrontier has=
 pretty standard configurable settings. Nothing new there
and the ChangeEva=
luator has none.
 
All the 'good stuff' is in the WaitEvaluator. It allows =
you to specify the
following:
Initial wait. A waiting period before revisit=
ing the first time.
Min and max values for the waiting times between visits=
.
Increase and decrease factors on unchanged and changed documents
respecti=
vely. Basically if a document has not changed between visits, it's
wait tim=
e will be multiplied by the "unchanged-factor" and if it has
changed, the w=
ait time will be divided by the "changed-factor". Both values
accept real n=
umbers, not just integers.
Finally, there is a 'default-wait-interval' this=
 is for URIs where it is not
possible to judge changes in content. Currentl=
y this applies only to DNS
lookups. 
 
If you want to specify different wai=
t times and factors for URIs based on
their mime types, this is possible. Y=
ou have to create a Refinement and use
the ContentType criteria. Simply use=
 a regular expression that matches the
desired mime type as it's parameter =
and then override the applicable
parameters in the refinement.
 

Some know=
n issues:
URIs that fail (negative fetch code) can cause trouble. This is m=
ost
noticeable if you have transitive inclusions in the scope. I.e. a URI
o=
utside the host your scope covers is deemed in scope because it's an embed,=

but it's robots.txt (for example) is not in scope because it is too many
e=
mbed hops away. This can cause the URI to be tried repeatedly.
 
It has not=
 been tested on anything more then 2 hosts (and small ones at
that).
 
By s=
etting the 'state' directory to the same location that an another AR
crawl =
used, it SHOULD resume that crawl (minus some stats). This is done by
utili=
zing some Berkeley DB's facilities and has not been tested well.
Especially=
 not if the crawl crashes badly.
 

The distro comes with the JavaDoc, whic=
h contains some additional technical
information for those who are interest=
ed.
 
 
The AR-addon is still in development and should not be considered s=
table. It
is however ready for testing, as all the functionality is there s=
o please,
if you are interested in this form of crawling, try it out and re=
port any
errors you encounter. You can e-mail me directly at kris (at) arch=
ive (dot)
org. Also feel free to e-mail me (or ask here on the list) if you=
 have any
technical questions about how the AR-addon does what it does.
 

=
Kristinn Sigur=F0sson
Software Developer
National and University Library of=
 Iceland
